Graphical abstract Ultrafine in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterojunction nanoparticles combine the advantages of NiO and Ni3N, and show stronger polysulfide adsorption and conversion capacity. Inhibiting the “shuttle effect” of soluble polysulfides and improving reaction kinetics are the key factors necessary for further exploration of high-performance Li-S batteries. Herein, an effective interface engineering strategy is reported, wherein nitriding of an Ni-based precursor is controlled to enhance Li-S cell regulation. The resulting in-situ formed NiO-Ni3N heterostructure interface not only has a stronger polysulfide adsorption effect than that of monomeric NiO or Ni3N but also has a faster Li ion diffusion ability than a simple physical mixture. More importantly, this approach couples the respective advantages of NiO and Ni3N to reduce polarization and facilitate electron transfer during polysulfide reactions and synergistically catalyze polysulfide conversion. In addition, ultrafine nanoparticles are thought to effectively improve the use of additive materials. In summary, Li-S batteries based on this NiO-Ni3N heterostructure have the features of long cycle stability, rapid charging-discharging, and good performance under high sulfur loading. Keywords NiO-Ni3N heterostructure Interface effect Ultrafine nanoparticles Li-S batteries Polysulfides 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered to be the most promising type of next-generation rechargeable energy storage due to their high theoretical capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) [1,2]. Nevertheless, a rapid rate of capacity decay and poor rate of performance limit their practical applications. These limitations are mainly due to the “shuttle effect” of soluble polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8), wherein Li2S x moves back and forth between the cathode and anode and produces disproportionation reactions, and slow reaction kinetics caused by complex multi-electron reactions [3,4]. To solve the above difficulties, many approaches such as homogeneous mediators and carbon regulation have been developed [5–9]. For instance, Lee et al. found that EV(ClO4)2 acted as the redox mediator could spontaneously react with S/Li2S to produce soluble polysulfides [6]. This mediator-assisted approach improves the reaction kinetics and performance by reusing inactive S/Li2S solids in high loading sulfur cathode. Carbon-based conductive materials with high surface areas, such as porous carbon [10], graphene [11], carbon nanotubes [12], and activated carbon (AC) [13], have been used to physically trap polysulfides. Huang et al. presented a double-layer carbon configuration to improve the sulfur content and electrochemical performance [9]. The additional carbon layer on the surface of C/S composite electrode was proved to provide more active sites and improve the sulfur utilization. However, as nonpolar carbon surfaces are not compatible with polar polysulfides, they cannot fully trap soluble Li2S x . This limitation is not conducive to long-term cycling. More importantly, carbon materials cannot effectively improve polysulfide conversion kinetics [14–16]. Therefore, attention has been gradually shifted to metallic compounds with polar surfaces, such as oxides, sulfides, nitrides, and phosphides [4,17–20]. These polar materials exhibit either strong polysulfide chemisorption or an excellent catalytic conversion ability [21,22]. As sulfur cathode additives or hosts, they can effectively anchor soluble Li2S x or accelerate reaction kinetics to suppress the shuttle effect. An ideal Li-S cathode additive or carrier should possess the dual functions of adsorption and catalysis while ensuring good electronic conductivity and minimizing reaction resistance. However, it is difficult to integrate all of these beneficial properties into a single material [23]. Generally, some poorly conductive materials have outstanding polysulfide conversion efficiency but limited adsorption, and some highly conductive materials exhibit strong anchoring behavior but have a non-ideal catalytic ability [24]. One prominent example is Ni3N, a highly conductive material with a good adsorption effect that is considered to have a low polysulfide conversion activity; as another example, the semiconducting material NiO has been proven to have excellent catalytic ability [4,25–27]. Recent studies have shown that polysulfide regulation can be effectively improved by combining multiple functional nanomaterials to form heterostructures [3,23,24,28,29]. For instance, Hou and Lu constructed a V2O3-V8C7 binary heterojunction that combines the advantages of the highly adsorptive V2O3 and catalytic V8C7 to enhance the immobilization, migration, and conversion of polysulfides [29]. Other heterojunctions such as Nb4N5-Nb2O5 were similarly designed [28]. However, elements such as vanadium and niobium are low natural abundance and more expensive. By contrast, nickel can be considered a candidate for electrode material because of its low price and high annual yield. In addition to conduction, adsorption, and catalysis, polar nanomaterials should have an ultra-small or ultra-thin morphology. This feature is needed because polysulfide adsorption and conversion are completed on the substrate surface, and the atomic structure and arrangement of the surface layer play a key role in this process [30,31]. The internal material of a bulk structure not only makes little contribution to the required properties of polysulfides but also increases the electrode weight and reduces the energy density of the overall battery. Meanwhile, a smaller size provides a higher specific surface area with more active sites. Therefore, minimization of the size of the polar material additives is an important development in the production of high-performance Li-S batteries [30]. The in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure nanoparticles described herein were prepared using a simple and mild method (Fig. 1 a). The “in-situ” refers to the fact that NiO and Ni3N were directly converted from precursor in one step, rather than simply physical mixtures [24,28]. The particle nanostructure effectively coupled the effects of the metallic material Ni3N and the semiconductor NiO on polysulfides. The ultrafine nanoparticle format greatly improved the utilization rate and active site content of the materials. More importantly, the heterostructure nanoparticles exhibited an unexpectedly rapid charge transfer and enhanced polysulfide adsorption and catalytic behavior due to the atomic bonding at the in-situ interface (Fig. 1b). An NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite cathode was shown to deliver enhanced high rate capability (681 mAh g−1 at a C-rate of 4 C) and a long life (500 cycles at a 0.07% decay rate per cycle). It was also shown to yield a promising electrochemical performance, even at high sulfur loadings of 2.7–6.0 mg cm−2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of NiO-Ni3N heterostructure nanoparticles Briefly, 5.1 g of NaOH were dissolved in 36 mL of NaClO (5%). The resulting pale yellow solution was slowly added to 35 mL of 1.7 M Ni2SO4. After stirring for 110 min, the precipitate was collected, washed several times with deionized water until the supernatant reached a pH of approximately 7 and dried at 50 °C. Finally, the NiO-Ni3N nanoparticles were prepared from this precursor material by using an in-situ nitridation method. Briefly, the precursor was annealed in a gaseous mixture of NH3 (100 standard cubic centimeters per minute, sccm) and Ar (150 sccm) at 350 °C (10 °C min−1) for 60 min. 2.2 Synthesis of the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite Although ultrafine nanomaterials have the disadvantage of agglomeration, this is mitigated by means such as ultrasound-assisted methods. Therefore, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite was fabricated using a similar dissolving-heating method [3]. Briefly, NiO-Ni3N nanoparticles, AC powder, and sublimed sulfur at a weight ratio of 2:1:7 were dispersed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) and CS2 solution under ultrasonication. The resulting solution was maintained at 50 °C to evaporate CS2 and organic solvents. The remaining mixture was heated at 155 °C in an Ar-sealed autoclave to obtain the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite. The sulfur content was about 70%. For comparison, other samples were prepared using the same method, namely NiO + Ni3N-AC-S, wherein NiO + Ni3N (simple physical mixture) was replaced with NiO-Ni3N, and AC-S, wherein NiO-Ni3N was replaced with additional AC. Similar assembly methods and names included NiO-AC-S and Ni3N-AC-S electrodes. 2.3 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku D/Max III device under Cu K α radiation. The morphologies of the as-obtained materials were characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM) with an FEI Tecnai G2 20 device. The corresponding high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) data were obtained at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The high-angle annular detector dark-field (HAADF) based scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) data were recorded on a Talos F200x device (Thermo Fisher). After the solids were fully dissolved, individual mixtures of AC, Ni3N, or NiO (at the same weight) were added to Li2S4 solution, respectively. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements The S cathodes were assembled by slurry casting using a mixture of the as-prepared materials (NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite and the AC-S and NIO + Ni3N-AC-S corresponding comparison samples), Super P, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as a binder at a weight ratio 8:1:1 in NMP. Using a Celgard-2300 membrane as the separator, coin cells were fabricated in an Ar-filled glovebox with metallic Li as the anode. The electrolyte was 1 mol L−1 bis-(trifluoromethane) sulfonimide lithium (LiTFSI) and 1 wt% LiNO3 in a 1:1 (v/v) mixture of DME and DOL. Under normal conditions, the ratios of electrolyte vs. sulfur (E/S) were 15 μL mg−1 (typical loading of 1.0 mg cm−2) and 10 μL mg−1 (high sulfur loadings), respectively. The electrode area was 0.785 cm−2 and the negative to positive capacity ratio (N/P) was about 19.3. To produce symmetric cells, the electrodes were fabricated without elemental sulfur. NiO-Ni3N nanoparticles or other comparison samples (∼80 wt%) were mixed with PVDF (10 wt%) and Super P (10 wt%) in NMP, cast on Al foil, and dried. The obtained electrodes were used as both working and counter electrodes. Each electrolyte contained 0.5 mol L−1 Li2S4 and 1 mol L−1 LiTFSI in DME and DOL solution (1:1 vol/vol). Galvanostatic charge-discharge was conducted using a Land battery tester. A Bio-Logic VSP potentiostat and CHI 760E electrochemical working station were used to conduct cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at frequencies ranging from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. 3 Results and discussion Density functional theory (DFT) calculations (see Supplementary Information) were first performed to illustrate the rationality and advantages of the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure in terms of Li-S batteries. Fig. 2 shows the optimal configuration and adsorption energy values of soluble polysulfides adsorbed on the NiO (101) surface, Ni3N (111) surface, and NiO-Ni3N heterostructure interface. The polysulfide molecules were shown to be stable on the substrates and to maintain a good structure (Fig. 2a–c). Different from the weak adsorption on pure carbon, the polysulfides exhibited higher binding energies on NiO, Ni3N, and NiO-Ni3N (Fig. 2d). This was because Li2S x formed chemical bonds with the nickel-containing surfaces, whereas the carbon surface only interacted with Li2S x through relatively weak van der Waals (vdW) forces (Fig. S1) [32,33]. Ni3N was found to have a higher binding energy than NiO. Interestingly, when NiO and Ni3N formed the in-situ heterostructure, the polysulfide binding energies at the interface were much higher than those of either the NiO or Ni3N surface. Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 had adsorption energies of 4.9, 3.7, and 4.1 eV, respectively, which were specific to the heterojunction interfaces and polysulfides; although high, these values were not sufficient to cause Li2S x decomposition [33]. The enhanced adsorbability of the heterostructure might be due to the numerous vacancies at the NiO–Ni3N interface [4,34]. For instance, oxygen vacancies at the NiO interface of the heterojunction could enhance the Ni d-band center, resulting in a stronger interaction between the sample and the Li-S reaction intermediates (Fig. S2) [4,35,36]. These findings, taken together, indicated that the heterostructure was suitable as a sulfur species adsorbent. The electronic conductivities of NiO-Ni3N heterostructure, monomeric NiO and Ni3N were calculated via partial density of states (DOS) plots (Fig. S3). The pure NiO was well known as a P-type semiconductor and its conductivity was poor, while Ni3N had a metallic characteristic. It was noteworthy that after engineering the in-situ heterojunction, the presence of Ni–N bonds in NiO-Ni3N could significantly modify the DOS near the Fermi level and tune the electron density. The band structure crossed the Fermi level, indicating the excellent conductivity of NiO-Ni3N, which would be conducive to the rapid transfer of electrons and polysulfide conversion [30]. The XRD patterns of the as-obtained samples are shown in Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. S4(a). The diffraction peaks of NiO (JCPDS No. 44-1159) and Ni3N (JCPDS No. 10-0280) suggested that the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure was successfully fabricated by the specific nitridation process. Combining the results of XPS with those of weight difference analysis after further nitridation revealed that the ratio of NiO to Ni3N was 1.96:1. The diffraction peaks of each substance remained nearly intact after mixing with sulfur powder and AC (Fig. S4). Nanocrystallization of polar materials is beneficial because it exposes more active sites, thus improving the utilization rates of materials and energy density of Li-S batteries [37]. Fig. 3(b) presents a TEM image of the NiO-Ni3N nanoparticles, which were ultrafine and uniform, with an average particle size of 7–11 nm. The multiple rings in Fig. 3(c) confirmed that the NiO-Ni3N nanoparticles were polycrystalline. Labeling of the composite of NiO and Ni3N with the rotational integral from the SAED pattern revealed a result consistent with the XRD result. Furthermore, the clear fringe spacings of 0.241 and 0.204 nm observed via HRTEM (Fig. 3d) were easily indexed to the (101) plane of NiO and (111) plane of Ni3N, respectively. The intimate interfacial conjunction was clear. Fig. 3(e) shows the HAADF-based STEM and EDS elemental mapping results. Evidently, the uniform dispersion of elemental Ni, O, and N indicated the distribution of the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure. Such small nanoparticles were found to have a BET surface area of up to 144.3 m2 g−1 (Fig. 3f), which should be conducive to the exposure of more active sites, thus promoting polysulfide adsorption and conversion reactions [4,37]. The pore size distribution of approximately 4 nm might be attributable to accumulation between nanoparticles, suggesting the capacity for rapid Li ion diffusion [38]. The fully assembled Li-S batteries were first tested by CV. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathode exhibited excellent reversibility and a typical Li-S reaction mechanism at a series of scan rates (0.1–0.9 mV s−1). The two strong cathodic peaks of C1 (2.3–2.35 V) and C2 (2.0–2.06 V) were assigned to the reduction of sulfur to long-chain polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and further reduction to solid-state Li2S2/Li2S, respectively. The broad anodic peak (A) at approximately 2.4 V was attributed to the corresponding oxidation process [2,24]. In addition to adsorption, the rapid transfer of charge is another important factor that accelerates the conversion of polysulfides [22,29]. To explore the contribution of the in-situ formed heterojunction to Li ion diffusion, NiO and Ni3N nanoparticles in the same proportions as those in the ratio of NiO to Ni3N in the in-situ heterojunctuion were mechanically mixed and used as a comparison sample. Here, NiO or Ni3N (Fig. S4b) was prepared using the same precursor as the heterojunction to ensure that they remained at the same level (see Supplementary Information). According to the classical Randles-Sevcik equation: Ip = (2.69 × 105)n 1.5 SD 0.5 Cν 0.5, where Ip is the peak current, n is the number of electrons transferred, S is the active electrode area, C is the Li ion concentration and ν is the scan rate, the Li ion diffusion coefficient (D) is positively correlated with the slope of the curve (Ip /ν 0.5) [22,39]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), all peak currents were linear with the square roots of the scan rates. The AC-S cathode yielded the lowest slopes, indicating that pure carbon was less effective in rapid electrochemical reactions and might result in highly viscous polysulfides and a thick insulation layer on the electrode surface [21]. In contrast, when Ni-based additives were used, the cathodes exhibited faster Li ion diffusivity. Moreover, the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure yielded much higher slopes than those of the mechanically mixed NiO and Ni3N nanoparticles (NiO + Ni3N-AC-S) in both polysulfide reduction and oxidation reactions, implying that the in-situ heterostructure enhanced Li ion diffusion [3,40–42]. By carefully inspecting the CV curves generated by the five samples (NiO-Ni3N-AC-S, NiO + Ni3N-AC-S, NiO-AC-S, Ni3N-AC-S, and AC-S) at the same scanning rate (0.1 mV s−1, Fig. 4c and Fig. S5), it was evident that compared with the AC-S electrode curve, the curves of the other four samples demonstrated redox peaks that tended to align with the quasi-equilibrium potentials. The lowest and highest potentials were measured for the anodic and cathodic peaks of NiO-Ni3N-AC-S, respectively, suggesting that the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterojunction could further enhance polysulfide reaction kinetics [43]. Fig. S6 displays the Tafel plots and fitted slope values for the reduction peaks of the CV curves in Fig. 4(c). Slope values as low as 37.6 and 17.2 mV dec−1 indicated that the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure yielded the strongest polysulfide catalytic capacity [44,45]. In this case, the accumulation of polysulfides and intensification of the “shuttle effect” would be avoided [23]. To validate these observations, symmetrical cells were assembled and tested (Fig. S7). As shown in Fig. 4(d), compared with AC and NiO + Ni3N, NiO-Ni3N yielded a higher CV current, and AC yielded a current of almost zero; these results indicated that the in-situ heterojunction increased catalytic activity, whereas carbon had almost no catalytic ability [14]. Fig. S8 shows the CV curves of pure NiO and Ni3N symmetrical cells. It could be seen that the peak current potential of Ni3N was actually a little bit better than the peak current of NiO. The gap was very small. Considering the poor conductivity of NiO, it seemed to suggest that NiO itself had stronger catalysis. In Fig. 4(e), the semicircular diameter of the impedance spectrum of the symmetrical NiO-Ni3N cell was the smallest. Based on the results of the equivalent circuit fitting (Fig. S9), its charge-transfer resistance (R ct) was greatly reduced, indicating as-prepared NiO-Ni3N heterostructure yielded the highest catalytic activity in polysulfide reactions [4,14,46]. The improved catalytic performance of the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterojunction relative to the mechanical mixture of NiO and Ni3N nanoparticles was due not only to its ability to provide more active interfaces but also to the combination of strong polysulfide anchoring, effective catalysis by NiO, and the good conductivity of Ni3N. In depth, the heterogeneous interface elongated most of the S–S bonds in polysulfides (especially the end-group S–S, in Fig. S10), meaning that the S–S bonds were weakened, which promoted the bond-breaking conversion of polysulfides [4,47]. In summary, the results of electrochemical analyses indicated that the in-situ formed NiO-Ni3N heterostructure enabled faster surface Li ion diffusion and better electrochemical reaction kinetics, consistent with previous reports [29,48]. These advantages should enable subsequent improvements in Li-S battery performance. Using Li foil as the anode, Li-S batteries were fabricated using the above three samples and systematically investigated. Fig. 5 (a) presents an evaluation of the rate capabilities of the three samples, and Fig. 5(b) shows the corresponding galvanostatic charge-discharge profiles between 1.7 and 2.6 V. These profiles were consistent with the results of CV, and the detailed lithiation and delithiation processes were described in Fig. S11 [49]. The sulfur mass loading was 1.0 mg cm−2. Compared with the AC-S and NiO + Ni3N-AC-S cathodes, the electrode based on in-situ NiO-Ni3N had a higher capacity at the same rates. As the C-rate increased from 0.2 to 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 C, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S electrode delivered high capacities of approximately 1179, 952, 840, 755, and 652 mAh g−1, respectively. The specific capacity calculations were based on the mass of active sulfur. Current conversion and cycling might result in a slight loss of capacity. The AC-S electrode was found to be unstable when the rate switched to 2 C, resulting in a capacity of <150 mAh g−1 at 4 C. After returning to 0.2 C, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S electrode capacity recovered to 952 mAh g−1, which was superior to the recovered capacities of the NiO + Ni3N-AC-S (885 mAh g−1) and AC-S electrodes (812 mAh g−1). Note that the direct contribution of NiO-Ni3N to battery capacity was negligible. The reversible capacity of the heterostructure in the voltage range of 1.7–2.6 V was only around 10 mAh g−1 (Fig. S12), indicating that the capacity of the as-prepared composite electrode was almost entirely derived from the electrochemical reaction of sulfur and Li. The excellent dynamics of the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure were also reflected in the polarization (ΔE) of the charge-discharge curve [50,51]. Although little difference was observed in the polarization of the three electrodes at low current densities (e.g., 0.2 C), the difference became increasingly obvious as the rate increased. The polarization of NiO-Ni3N-AC-S was markedly lower than that of the other two sample electrodes at the same current rates (Fig. 5c). To investigate the cycle stability of the Li-S batteries with heterostructure additives, constant-current charge-discharge tests were performed at low and high rates. At 0.5 C, all of the electrodes exhibited similar trends in Coulombic efficiency (Fig. 5d). In the first few cycles, the Coulombic efficiency gradually increased and tended to remain stable (NiO-Ni3N-AC-S: 99.9%, NiO + Ni3N-AC-S: 99.6%, AC-S: 99.1%). The worse performance at 40th cycle might be caused by many aspects. For example, the formation of Li dendrites leaded to the instability of solid electrolyte interphase and anode structure, resulting in the increase of interface resistance and the decrease of capacity; the diffusion of a small amount of polysulfides to the anode caused the loss of active species, resulting in the acceleration of capacity attenuation. The differences in capacity retention were observed after 100 cycles. The NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathode showed the highest retention rate of ∼83.1%, with a reversible discharge capacity of 818 mAh g−1. In comparison, the NiO + Ni3N-AC-S sample yielded a gradual fading process with a relatively low retention rate of ∼64.9% and a capacity of 598 mAh g−1. Fig. S13 shows the cycle performance of NiO-AC-S and Ni3N-AC-S electrodes at the same rate. It could be seen that their capacity retention rate was lower than that of the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S heterostructure. More seriously, the AC-S cathode exhibited a more obvious and rapid decrease in discharge capacity of 314 mAh g−1 at the 100th cycle, corresponding to a retention of only ∼35.1% of its initial capacity. This finding revealed that the polysulfides in the cathode without the Ni-based additive were subject to a serious “shuttle effect” [52], which was visually verified by the shuttle current test data shown in Fig. S14 [44,53]. Typically, after being fully charged, the Li-S battery was discharged to 2.38 V and then entered the potentiostatic mode. The shuttle current of the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S composite was lower than that of the AC-S composite, indicating the powerful polysulfide anchoring ability and higher sulfur utilization of the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure. The long-term cycling performance of the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S electrode at a high current density (4 C) is shown in Fig. 5(g). The curve demonstrates that the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathode had a high initial capacity of 681 mAh g−1 and superior stability, with a low capacity decay of ∼0.07% per cycle (batter than 0.1% of NiO + Ni3N-AC-S electrode). After 500 cycles, its Coulombic efficiency remained at 99.5%. For AC-S sample, although its capacity decline rate was very small, such low capacity at high rate made it almost no application value. In order to explore the effect of electrolyte amount on electrochemical performance, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathodes with different E/S ratios were evaluated (Fig. S15). Although high E/S results in higher sulfur utilization and capacity, it might lead to the dissolution of large amounts of polysulfides, reducing the cycle life [54]. The low E/S ratio made the active materials not fully permeated, and the electrolyte viscosity increased due to the dissolution of polysulfides, which led to slow ion transfer and affected the utilization of sulfur [55]. Moreover, Fig. S16 shows the cycling performance of NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathode with different N/P ratios. It could be seen that even at N/P values as low as 10 and 5.0, the in-situ heterostructure electrode still obtained the maximum specific capacities of 1183 and 1121 mAh g−1, with corresponding energy densities of ∼410 and ∼596 Wh kg−1 (based on the total mass of the composite cathode and the anode), respectively. The three Li-S batteries were further compared by EIS measurements at the 20th cycle. As shown in Fig. 5(e), all Nyquist plots showed similar curves: a depressed semicircle in the high-frequency region and a subsequent straight line in the low-frequency region. Based on the results of the equivalent circuit (Fig. S9) fitting, the AC-S electrode with a large semicircular diameter exhibited the highest R ct of 17.9 Ω and surface film resistance (R suf) of 26.7 Ω, which might be caused by two factors [56]. First, AC did not promote the conversion of polysulfides [14,21]. Second, during the cycle, a large amount of polysulfides diffused to the Li anode surface, inducing disproportionation reactions to form insulating Li2S or Li2S2 coating and resulting in poor interfacial resistance [29,57]. In contrast, cells based on Ni-based additives effectively avoided above issues and exhibited low resistances. The R ct and R suf of NiO + Ni3N-AC-S based battery were 4.5 and 8.3 Ω, respectively. In particular, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S samlpe with the smallest semicircular Nyquist plot diameter showed the lower resistances (R ct of 2.6 Ω and R suf of 5.8 Ω), further demonstrating the promoting effect of the in-situ heterostructure on polysulfide adsorption and conversion [58]. Compared with NiO + Ni3N mixed sample, the improved kinetics and stability of the in-situ heterostructure might be due to the following reasons. Firstly, the NiO/Ni3N heterostructure was derived from in-situ nitriding. Different from the vdW heterojunction obtained by vdW force, this in-situ transformed structure might result in chemical interaction at the NiO/Ni3N interface. Due to the different lattice structure and chemical composition of NiO and Ni3N phases, lots of defects and dislocations were easily formed at the interface (Fig. S2) [59]. Defects in the interface could form impurity levels in the electronic structure, which might be active sites for polysulfide reactions [60,61]. In addition, compared with the preparation method of simple physical mixing of NiO and Ni3N, in-situ transformation could obtain more uniform heterostructures on the micro scale [28]. The active sulfur loading per unit area is another important criterion of Li-S battery performance [22,52]. Fig. 5(f) shows the cycling performance of the composite cathode based on the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure at different high sulfur loadings (2.7–6.0 mg cm−2). With a loading of 3.4 mg cm−2, the maximum area capacity of NiO + Ni3N-AC-S cathode was 3.5 mAh cm−2 (1028 mAh g−1, 0.2 C), which could maintain a high capacity of 2.4 mAh cm−2 even at the 100th cycle. At 0.5 C, the highest reversible capacities of 2.3, 2.0, and 2.4 mAh cm−2 (846, 639, and 404 mAh g−1) were achieved for the cathodes with sulfur loadings of 2.7, 3.1, and 6.0 mg cm−2, respectively. The corresponding ΔE values were only 0.20, 0.22, and 0.28 V, respectively (Fig. S17). These results implied that the excellent kinetics of the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure were maintained under the condition of increasing sulfur loading. After cycling, the retention rates relative to the initial capacity were 81.5% (100 cycles), 87.8% (100 cycles) and 74.8% (50 cycles), respectively. At higher rates of 2 and 1 C, the NiO-Ni3N-AC-S cathodes with sulfur loadings of 2.7 and 4.4 mg cm−2 delivered high initial capacities of 1.5 mAh cm−2 (566 mAh g−1) and 2.2 mAh cm−2 (503 mAh g−1), respectively. Decent circulation stability was also observed. In general, such high rate, low capacity attenuation, and high loading of NiO-Ni3N-AC-S were superior to most of the previous and recent literatures (Fig. S18). In addition, the metallic Li anodes from recycled cells were isolated for post-mortem analysis. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), similar to previous reports [4,47], the Li anode surface disassembled from the AC-S-paired cell had a distinct rough and porous structure. This was caused by the disproportionation reaction of the soluble polysulfides with Li metal, which led to severe anodic corrosion [47,62]. In contrast, the metallic anode in the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure-based battery had a relatively flat structure (Fig. 6b), indicating mitigation of the “shuttle effect” of polysulfides. The corresponding EDS spectra (Fig. 6c and d) display that the content of sulfur on the Li metal of NiO-Ni3N-AC-S battery was less than that of AC-S battery, indicating the diffusion of polysulfides to the anode was inhibited. Moreover, the NiO-Ni3N heterostructure nanoparticles maintained relative stability during the Li-S battery cycle (Fig. S19). All of the above electrochemical stability data showed that the as-obtained NiO-Ni3N heterojunction had a powerful anchoring effect on polysulfides. To observe this advantage in a more intuitive way, Fig. 7 (a and b) display the direct adsorption strengths of different materials for Li2S4. After 1.5 h, NiO, Ni3N, and NiO-Ni3N all induced discoloration of the Li2S4 solution to different degrees. Evidently, NiO-Ni3N had the best adsorption effect, resulting in almost complete clarification of the corresponding L2S4 solution, whereas the solutions treated with NiO and Ni3N samples were yellow and light yellow, respectively. This result was consistent with the previous theoretical calculations (Fig. 2). In addition, the defects introduced by this method might also be the reason for the stronger adsorption of Ni3N (Fig. S20) [4]. The adsorption effects of NiO and Ni3N did not induce transparency until the 4-hour time point, and the color of the AC sample hardly changed. From the theoretical calculations, this adsorption difference could also be shown intuitively by electron charge transfer analysis [33]. As shown in Fig. 7(c), compared with the NiO or Ni3N monomer, introduction of the heterostructure interface made the surface atoms more electron-enriched, indicating increased charge transfer between the substrate and Li2S4 and a stronger bonding effect [4,23,47]. The adsorption mechanism of NiO-Ni3N was further explored in combination with high-resolution XPS [28]. For the initial NiO-Ni3N sample, the Ni 2p 3/2 signal was composed of a main peak, which could be fitted into two peaks, and its satellite peak (Fig. 7d). The lower energy level peaks at 854.1 and 856.1 eV represented Ni–N and Ni2+, respectively [63,64]. The peak at the N 1s position (398 eV) could be attributed to the Ni–N bond (Fig. 7e), and the weak peak at ∼399.8 eV might be associated with surface oxygen adsorption from air [65]. These results were consistent with the XRD pattern, indicating the formation of the NiO-Ni3N heterojunction. The Ni 2p spectrum of the NiO-Ni3N sample after adsorption of Li2S4 revealed a shift in the Ni–N and Ni2+ peaks to a higher binding energy (i.e., red-shift), indicating the transfer of electrons from Ni atoms to Li2S4 after adsorption, consistent with previous reports [32,66]. To some extent, these transferred electrons filled the lowest occupied orbital of the polysulfide, which weakened the S–S bonds and promoted conversion [4]. This strong chemical bonding effectively inhibited the “shuttle effect” of polysulfides and provided a basis for subsequent catalytic conversion, which greatly improved the overall performance of Li–S batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, NiO-Ni3N heterostructure nanoparticles with diameters of 7–11 nm were prepared using a simple and controllable precipitation-nitriding technique. Ultrafine nanoparticles not only provide more active sites but also help to maximize the utilization of polar materials and improve the energy density of Li-S batteries. More importantly, experimental tests and theoretical calculations were used to demonstrate the following unexpected interfacial effects of the in-situ NiO-Ni3N heterostructure. First, the heterojunction interface, as the active site, was shown to have a stronger ability to anchor soluble polysulfides than NiO or Ni3N alone. Second, unlike mechanical mixtures, the in-situ formed interface provided a medium for rapid diffusion of Li ions. Third, by combining the good catalytic performance of NiO and the excellent electrical conductivity of Ni3N, the NiO-Ni3N interface could further enhance the conversion efficiency of polysulfides and improve the reaction kinetics of the cell. Thanks to these advantages, a Li-S battery based on the in-situ formed heterojunction nanoparticles revealed an impressive rate capability of 681 mAh g−1 at 4 C, and a slow capacity decay rate of ∼0.07% per cycle across 500 galvanostatic charge-discharge cycles. This strategy based on in-situ heterostructure nanoparticles is expected to be a promising candidate for the further development of highly efficient additives for next-generation Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Inhibiting the “shuttle effect” of soluble polysulfides and improving reaction kinetics are the key factors necessary for further exploration of high-performance Li-S batteries. Herein, an effective interface engineering strategy is reported, wherein nitriding of an Ni-based precursor is controlled to enhance Li-S cell regulation. The resulting in-situ formed NiO-Ni3N heterostructure interface not only has a stronger polysulfide adsorption effect than that of monomeric NiO or Ni3N but also has a faster Li ion diffusion ability than a simple physical mixture. More importantly, this approach couples the respective advantages of NiO and Ni3N to reduce polarization and facilitate electron transfer during polysulfide reactions and synergistically catalyze polysulfide conversion. In addition, ultrafine nanoparticles are thought to effectively improve the use of additive materials. In summary, Li-S batteries based on this NiO-Ni3N heterostructure have the features of long cycle stability, rapid charging-discharging, and good performance under high sulfur loading.
